content:
Which is your email provider? If you post a screenshot of your outgoing (SMTP) server settings, we may verify they're correct.

Read the following article in the meantime to see possible causes of the problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages

In particular, if you're using a VPN, disable it and see whether that makes the problem go away. If it does, check whether your VPN has an option called split tunneling which would allow you to let Thunderbird bypass the VPN.
creator: DavidGG

content:
What timeout symbol? Can you post a screenshot? What type of account is this (POP, IMAP)?

Start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode. The following article explains how to do that and why it can be useful to help identify the cause of a problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

What's your operating system? If Windows, start in Safe Mode with Networking mode. You may have to connect your computer to the router with an Ethernet cable, WiFi is disabled in Safe Mode:

https://support.microsoft.com/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode

Does any of that make the problem go away?
creator: DavidGG

content: If the Folder Pane layout is not retained between restarts, try this: Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, delete or rename folderTree.json and session.json. Restart TB and see if the layout is preserved.
creator: sfhowes

content: I think you mean a > and if you click on the > you will expand the list to show the folders that are collapsed under the one with the >
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
What Matt said, but if this has taken you by surprise, it could be that you're used to All Folders view and switched to Unified Folders view:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/switching-folder-pane-view
creator: DavidGG

content:
That will be the storage on one of your accounts is 82% full, not Thunderbird.

Recently i have seen a lot of folks that store photos on googles drive getting issues with their google storage getting quite full as Google do not offer a separate allocation of space for mail and "other stuff', it is all in the same space allocation of 15Gb.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
That doesn't really make sense. What are you observing that makes you think you have "82% full of your Thunderbird email program"?

Is the problem that you have too much mail stored on the server and you don't know how to remove it from there? What type of mail account is this (POP, IMAP)?
creator: DavidGG

content:
The way to accomplish this would be some generic form of filesystem encryption, not something specific to Thunderbird, but what you have to encrypt is the profile folder where all your mail data is stored, not the Thunderbird application itself:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data
creator: DavidGG

content:
Are you aware of user account controls in your operating system, they are more than capable of encrypting the data stored in the user account, including Thunderbird mail and all your other documents and tax records.

I have been hearing folk on about encryption at rest and refusing to use the facilities of the operating system that allow that for decades. I still fail to understand why anyone wants encryption amateurs (email developers) to encrypt data when they already have access to something written and tested over 20 or more years to be secure.

See https://www.cbtnuggets.com/tutorials/encrypt-data-at-rest-with-linux-tools and https://linuxsecurity.com/features/the-ultimate-guide-to-using-data-encryption-on-linux

Those are a couple of google result for Linux, which the forum reports you as using.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: You will always need a password or some other form of authentication to log into your mail account, of course, but Thunderbird can save the password so you don't have to type it every time. Doesn't Thunderbird give you the option to save the password? Or it does, but doesn't save it? Or do you get an error after entering the password? Or what? More info, please…
creator: DavidGG

content: The username is usually the same as the email address. The server settings needed to set up the account may be publicly available, in which case you may be able to figure them by googling "email settings" for your email provider. Which is your email provider?
creator: DavidGG

content:
What do you mean it continues like this for hours? Does it keep showing that error message until it finally succeeds? Can you normally use Thunderbird until then otherwise?

Do you have other accounts listed in Account Settings in Thunderbird that you don't have in Outlook?

If you're using a VPN, disable it and see whether that makes the problem go away. If it does, check whether your VPN has an option called split tunneling which would allow you to let Thunderbird bypass the VPN.

Start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode. The following article explains how to do that and why it can be useful to help identify the cause of a problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

What's your operating system? If Windows, start in Safe Mode with Networking mode. You may have to connect your computer to the router with an Ethernet cable, WiFi is disabled in Safe Mode:

https://support.microsoft.com/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode

Does any of that make the problem go away?
creator: DavidGG

content:
Se l'account era di tipo IMAP e non hai fatto una copia locale, è probabile che la posta sia andata persa.

Si può recuperare se hai un backup.

Oppure si può provare con le tecniche descritte qui https://codeberg.org/m13o/TBook/wiki/Thunderbird+-+Importare+mbox.- Ma bisogna vedere cosa eventualmente è rimasto nel profilo.
creator: @next

content:
here are some recent discussions around Eudora. I sort of got sick of helping folks with it over 100 versions ago when there was a functional importer from Eudora, but as the product has been discontinued for more than a decade no one could be bothered fixing the importer for Eudora when it broke years ago. So there is no importer anymore, you have to use an ago appropriate version of Thunderbird.

Here are some recent discussion on Eudora from like minded individuals. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1470910#answer-1684294

Then there is the official documentation instructions https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/switching-thunderbird#w_importing-from-outlook-and-eudora Then there is https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1478773


That collectively should provide the information required. The most important being get an old copy of Thunderbird that actually knows what Eudora was and can import from it, the second being the version you import from must be installed and running. If you waited until it would not run, there is a high likelihood that the import will simply not work.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: What type of mail account is this (POP, IMAP)? What are your Account Settings > Copies & Folders > Message Archives settings? Do you have a single archive folder that may have become too big?

content:
Do you keep a lot of mail stored in Inbox?

Go to Account Settings > Server Settings, note the folder that appears in Local Directory, open that folder in the file manager of the OS you're using, and post a screenshot of the contents here.

Is setting up the account as IMAP an option, just to check whether Thunderbird can connect to the server and see the mail there using a different protocol?
